In the world of Christiandom, there are many and varied fantastic creatures. As for angels, it is commonly believed that they belong to a hierarchical order. Notably, Michael belongs in the archangel category. Gabriel is another of the elite archangels, revered by both Christians and Muslims. Incubi and Succubi are considered by many to be another class of angels, those of ill-repute, sexually preying on both men and women while they sleep. There was a belief that Incubi were attracted to female hair and is the reason for the custom of women wearing hats in church. In between these extremes are a host of other angels--Seraphim, Cherubim, Thrones, Dominions, Virtues, Powers and Principalities--as the belief goes, assisting God in various duties, crying over wayward souls and the like. This is where the guardian angel idea grew from, and as already explained, has no biblical foundation.
 
 I suppose it is quite natural for a person who has accepted the belief in an unseen god to further populate his or her imagination with more unearthly creatures. It seems like a small step to do so. After all, Christians for the most part believe also in a devil, and his minions, the demons, which are said to be quite numerous. In an account in Mark 5, for instance, it is said 2000 of them entered into the bodies of pigs at the command of Jesus and dove off a cliff. This is but one example. There are many accounts in the N.T. of possessed persons, presumably by some unseen evil spirit. Gargoyles were as real as you and me to many a Middle Ages Christian. 
 
 It is a common Christian belief, IMO, that forces of good are arrayed against forces of bad, and that these forces represent real extra-terrestrial beings, lined up in epic battle formations and fighting an ongoing 24/7 crusade for human being's souls.
 
 For my part, when I gave up my belief in the Christian God, the other characters melted away also. It was an exhilarating experience, and the sense of freedom and peace of mind stays with me to this day. I would recommend it to all readers.
